author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the Spaniards, therefore it was decided at a solemn council that Otomie
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and I her husband should go on an embassy to the chief town of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: nation, that was known as the City of Pines, and strive to win it back
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to the Aztec standard.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Accordingly, heralds having been sent before us, we started upon our
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: journey, not knowing how we should be received at the end of it. For
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: eight days we travelled in great pomp and with an ever-increasing
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: escort, for when the tribes of the Otomie learned that their princess
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: was come to visit them in person, bringing with her her husband, a man
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of the Teules who had espoused the Aztec cause, they flocked in vast
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: numbers to swell her retinue, so that it came to pass that before we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: reached the City of Pines we were accompanied by an army of at least ten
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: thousand mountaineers, great men and wild, who made a savage music as we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: marched. But with them and with their chiefs as yet we held no converse
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: except by way of formal greeting, though every morning when we started
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: on our journey, Otomie in a litter and I on a horse that had been
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: captured from the Spaniards, they set up shouts of salutation and made
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the mountains ring. Ever as we went the land like its people grew wilder
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and more beautiful, for now we were passing through forests clad with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: oak and pine and with many a lovely plant and fern. Sometimes we crossed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: great and sparkling rivers and sometimes we wended through gorges and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: passes of the mountains, but every hour we mounted higher, till at
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: length the climate became like that of England, only far more bright. At
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: last on the eighth day we passed through a gorge riven in the red rock,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: which was so narrow in places that three horsemen could scarcely have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ridden there abreast. This gorge, that is five miles long, is the high
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: road to the City of Pines, to which there was no other access except by
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: secret paths across the mountains, and on either side of it are sheer
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and towering cliffs that rise to heights of between one and two thousand
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: feet.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Here is a place where a hundred men might hold an army at bay,' I said
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to Otomie, little knowing that it would be my task to do so in a day to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: come.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Presently the gorge took a turn and I reined up amazed, for before me
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: was the City of Pines in all its beauty. The city lay in a wheelshaped
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: plain that may measure twelve miles across, and all around this plain
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: are mountains clad to their summits with forests of oak and cedar trees.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: At the back of the city and in the centre of the ring of mountains is
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: one, however, that is not green with foliage but black with lava, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: above the lava white with snow, over which again hangs a pillar of smoke
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: by day and a pillar of fire by night. This was the volcan Xaca, or the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Queen, and though it is not so lofty as its sisters Orizaba, Popo, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Ixtac, to my mind it is the loveliest of them all, both because of its
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: perfect shape, and of the colours, purple and blue, of the fires that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: it sends forth at night or when its heart is troubled. The Otomies
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: worshipped this mountain as a god, offering human sacrifice to it, which
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: was not wonderful, for once the lava pouring from its bowels cut a path
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: through the City of Pines. Also they think it holy and haunted, so that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: none dare set foot upon its loftier snows. Nevertheless I was destined
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to climb them--I and one other.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Now in the lap of this ring of mountains and watched over by the mighty
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Xaca, clad in its robe of snow, its cap of smoke, and its crown of fire,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: lies, or rather lay the City of Pines, for now it is a ruin, or so I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: left it. As to the city itself, it was not so large as some others that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I have seen in Anahuac, having only a population of some five and thirty
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: thousand souls, since the Otomie, being a race of mountaineers, did
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: not desire to dwell in cities. But if it was not great, it was the most
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: beautiful of Indian towns, being laid out in straight streets that met
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: at the square in its centre. All along these streets were houses each
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: standing in a garden, and for the most part built of blocks of lava and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: roofed with a cement of white lime. In the midst of the square stood the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: teocalli or pyramid of worship, crowned with temples that were garnished
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with ropes of skulls, while beyond the pyramid and facing it, was the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: palace, the home of Otomie's forefathers, a long, low, and very ancient
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: building having many courts, and sculptured everywhere with snakes and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: grinning gods. Both the palace and the pyramid were cased with a fine
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: white stone that shone like silver in the sunlight, and contrasted
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: strangely with the dark-hued houses that were built of lava.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Such was the City of Pines when I saw it first. When I saw it last it
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: was but a smoking ruin, and now doubtless it is the home of bats and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: jackals; now it is 'a court for owls,' now 'the line of confusion is
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stretched out upon it and the stones of emptiness fill its streets.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Passing from the mouth of the gorge we travelled some miles across the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: plain, every foot of which was cultivated with corn, maguey or aloe, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: other crops, till we came to one of the four gates of the city. Entering
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: it we found the flat roofs on either side of the wide street crowded
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with hundreds of women and children who threw flowers on us as we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: passed, and cried, 'Welcome, princess! Welcome, Otomie, princess of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie!' And when at length we reached the great square, it seemed as
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: though all the men in Anahuac were gathered there, and they too took
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: up the cry of 'Welcome, Otomie, princess of the Otomie!' till the earth
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: shook with the sound. Me also they saluted as I passed, by touching the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: earth with their right hands and then holding the hand above the head,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: but I think that the horse I rode caused them more wonder than I did,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: for the most of them had never seen a horse and looked on it as a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: monster or a demon. So we went on through the shouting mass, followed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and preceded by thousands of warriors, many of them decked in glittering
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: feather mail and bearing broidered banners, till we had passed the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: pyramid, where I saw the priests at their cruel work above us, and were
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: come to the palace gates. And here in a strange chamber sculptured with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: grinning demons we found rest for a while.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: On the morrow in the great hall of the palace was held a council of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: chiefs and head men of the Otomie clans, to the number of a hundred or
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: more. When all were gathered, dressed as an Aztec noble of the first
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: rank, I came out with Otomie, who wore royal robes and looked most
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: beautiful in them, and the council rose to greet us. Otomie bade them be
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: seated and addressed them thus:
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Hear me, you chiefs and captains of my mother's race, who am your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: princess by right of blood, the last of your ancient rulers, and who am
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: moreover the daughter of Montezuma, Emperor of Anahuac, now dead to us
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: but living evermore in the Mansions of the Sun. First I present to you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: this my husband, the lord Teule, to whom I was given in marriage when
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: he held the spirit of the god Tezcat, and whom, when he had passed the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: altar of the god, being chosen by heaven to aid us in our war, I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: wedded anew after the fashion of the earth, and by the will of my royal
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: brethren. Know, chiefs and captains, that this lord, my husband, is not
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of our Indian blood, nor is he altogether of the blood of the Teules
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with whom we are at war, but rather of that of the true children of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Quetzal, the dwellers in a far off northern sea who are foes to the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Teules. And as they are foes, so this my lord is their foe, and as
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: doubtless you have heard, of all the deeds of arms that were wrought
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: upon the night of the slaying of the Teules, none were greater than his,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and it was he who first discovered their retreat.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Chiefs and captains of the great and ancient people of the Otomie, I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: your princess have been sent to you by Cuitlahua, my king and yours,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: together with my lord, to plead with you on a certain matter. Our king
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: has heard, and I also have heard with shame, that many of the warriors
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of our blood have joined the Tlascalans, who were ever foes to the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Aztecs, in their unholy alliance with the Teules. Now for a while the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: white men are beaten back, but they have touched the gold they covet,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and they will return again like bees to a half-drained flower. They
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: will return, yet of themselves they can do nothing against the glory of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Tenoctitlan. But how shall it go if with them come thousands and tens
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of thousands of the Indian peoples? I know well that now in this time
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of trouble, when kingdoms crumble, when the air is full of portents, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the very gods seem impotent, there are many who would seize the moment
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and turn it to their profit. There are many men and tribes who remember
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ancient wars and wrongs, and who cry, "Now is the hour of vengeance,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: now we will think on the widows that the Aztec spears have made, on the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: tribute which they have wrung from our poverty to swell their wealth,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and on the captives who have decked the altars of their sacrifice!"
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Is it not so? Ay, it is so, and I cannot wonder at it. Yet I ask you to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: remember this, that the yoke you would help to set upon the neck of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: queen of cities will fit your neck also. O foolish men, do you think
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that you shall be spared when by your aid Tenoctitlan is a ruin and the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Aztecs are no more a people? I say to you never. The sticks that the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Teules use to beat out the life of Tenoctitlan shall by them be broken
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: one by one and cast into the fire to burn. If the Aztecs fall, then
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: early or late every tribe within this wide land shall fall. They shall
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: be slain, their cities shall be stamped flat, their wealth shall be
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: wrung from them, and their children shall eat the bread of slavery and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: drink the water of affliction. Choose, ye people of the Otomie. Will you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stand by the men of your own customs and country, though they have been
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: your foes at times, or will you throw in your lot with the stranger?
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Choose, ye people of the Otomie, and know this, that on your choice and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that of the other men of Anahuac, depends the fate of Anahuac. I am your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: princess, and you should obey me, but to-day I issue no command. I say
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: choose between the alliance of the Aztec and the yoke of the Teule, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: may the god above the gods, the almighty, the invisible god, direct your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: choice.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie ceased and a murmur of applause went round the hall. Alas, I can
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: do no justice to the fire of her words, any more than I can describe the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: dignity and loveliness of her person as it seemed in that hour. But they
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: went to the hearts of the rude chieftains who listened. Many of them
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: despised the Aztecs as a womanish people of the plains and the lakes,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: a people of commerce. Many had blood feuds against them dating back for
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: generations. But still they knew that their princess spoke truth, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that the triumph of the Teule in Tenoctitlan would mean his triumph over
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: every city throughout the land. So then and there they chose, though
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: in after days, in the stress of defeat and trouble, many went back upon
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: their choice as is the fashion of men.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Otomie,' cried their spokesman, after they had taken counsel together,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'we have chosen. Princess, your words have conquered us. We throw in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: our lot with the Aztecs and will fight to the last for freedom from the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Teule.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Now I see that you are indeed my people, and I am indeed your ruler,'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: answered Otomie. 'So the great lords who are gone, my forefathers, your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: chieftains, would have spoken in a like case. May you never regret this
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: choice, my brethren, Men of the Otomie.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: And so it came to pass that when we left the City of Pines we took from
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: it to Cuitlahua the emperor, a promise of an army of twenty thousand men
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: vowed to serve him to the death in his war against the Spaniard.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: CHAPTER XXVI
title: Montezuma's Daughter

text: THE CROWNING OF GUATEMOC
title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: worst with him.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: sighing and her neck is heavy with chains. The children are visited
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: because of the evil of the fathers. Ye are doomed, people of Anahuac,
title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: cushions, and before the frightened leech who tended him could lift his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: head, he had passed beyond the troubles of this earth. But the words
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: translating his words.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I am Guatemoc, the emperor, Malinche,' he said. 'What a man might do to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: defend his people, I have done. Look on the fruits of my labour,' and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: he pointed to the blackened ruins of Tenoctitlan that stretched on every
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: side far as the eye could reach. 'Now I have come to this pass, for the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: gods themselves have been against me. Deal with me as you will, but it
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: will be best that you kill me now,' and he touched the dagger of Cortes
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with his hand, 'and thus rid me swiftly of the misery of life.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Fear not, Guatemoc,' answered Cortes. 'You have fought like a brave
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: man, and such I honour. With me you are safe, for we Spaniards love a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: gallant foe. See, here is food,' and he pointed to a table spread with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: such viands as we had not seen for many a week; 'eat, you and your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: companions together, for you must need it. Afterwards we will talk.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: So we ate, and heartily, I for my part thinking that it would be well to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: die upon a full stomach, having faced death so long upon an empty one,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and while we devoured the meat the Spaniards stood on one side scanning
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: us, not without pity. Presently, Tecuichpo was brought before
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Cortes, and with her Otomie and some six other ladies. He greeted her
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: graciously, and they also were given to eat. Now, one of the Spaniards
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: who had been watching me whispered something into the ear of Cortes, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I saw his face darken.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Say,' he said to me in Castilian, 'are you that renegade, that traitor
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: who has aided these Aztecs against us?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I am no renegade and no traitor, general,' I answered boldly, for the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: food and wine had put new life into me. 'I am an Englishman, and I have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fought with the Aztecs because I have good cause to hate you Spaniards.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You shall soon have better, traitor,' he said furiously. 'Here, lead
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: this man away and hang him on the mast of yonder ship.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Now I saw that it was finished, and made ready to go to my death, when
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Marina spoke into the ear of Cortes. All she said I could not catch, but
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I heard the words 'hidden gold.' He listened, then hesitated, and spoke
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: aloud: 'Do not hang this man to-day. Let him be safely guarded. Tomorrow
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I will inquire into his case.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: CHAPTER XXVIII
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: THOMAS IS DOOMED
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: At the words of Cortes two Spaniards came forward, and seizing me one
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: by either arm, they led me across the roof of the house towards the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stairway. Otomie had heard also, and though she did not understand the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: words, she read the face of Cortes, and knew well that I was being taken
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to imprisonment or death. As I passed her, she started forward, a terror
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: shining in her eyes. Fearing that she was about to throw herself upon
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: my breast, and thus to reveal herself as my wife, and bring my fate upon
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: her, I glanced at her warningly, then making pretence to stumble, as
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: though with fear and exhaustion, I fell at her feet. The soldiers who
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: led me laughed brutally, and one of them kicked me with his heavy boot.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: But Otomie stooped down and held her hand to me to help me rise, and as
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I did so, we spoke low and swiftly.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Farewell, wife,' I said; 'whatever happens, keep silent.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Farewell,' she answered; 'if you must die, await me in the gates of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: death, for I will join you there.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Nay, live on. Time shall bring comfort.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You are my life, beloved. With you time ends for me.' Now I was on my
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: feet again, and I think that none noted our whispered words, for all
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: were listening to Cortes, who rated the man that had kicked me.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I bade you guard this traitor, not to kick him,' he said angrily in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Castilian. 'Will you put us to open shame before these savages? Do
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: so once more, and you shall pay for it smartly. Learn a lesson in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: gentleness from that woman; she is starving, yet she leaves her food to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: help your prisoner to his feet. Now take him away to the camp, and see
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that he comes to no harm, for he can tell me much.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Then the soldiers led me away, grumbling as they went, and the last
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: thing that I saw was the despairing face of Otomie my wife, as she gazed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: after me, faint with the secret agony of our parting. But when I came
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to the head of the stairway, Guatemoc, who stood near, took my hand and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: shook it.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Farewell, my brother,' he said with a heavy smile; 'the game we played
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: together is finished, and now it is time for us to rest. I thank you for
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: your valour and your aid.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Farewell, Guatemoc,' I answered. 'You are fallen, but let this comfort
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: you, in your fall you have found immortal fame.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'On, on!' growled the soldiers, and I went, little thinking how Guatemoc
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and I should meet again.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: They took me to a canoe, and we were paddled across the lake by
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Tlascalans, till at length we came to the Spanish camp. All the journey
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: through, my guards, though they laid no hand on me, fearing the anger
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of Cortes, mocked and taunted me, asking me how I liked the ways of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: heathen, and whether I ate the flesh of the sacrifices raw or cooked;
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and many another such brutal jest they made at my expense. For a while I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: bore it, for I had learned to be patient from the Indians, but at last I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: answered them in few words and bitter.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Peace, cowards,' I said; 'remember that I am helpless, and that were I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: before you strong and armed, either I should not live to listen to such
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: words, or you would not live to repeat them.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Then they were silent, and I also was silent.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: When we reached their camp I was led through it, followed by a throng of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fierce Tlascalans and others, who would have torn me limb from limb had
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: they not feared to do so. I saw some Spaniards also, but the most
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of these were so drunk with mescal, and with joy at the tidings that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Tenoctitlan had fallen, and their labours were ended at last, that they
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: took no heed of me. Never did I see such madness as possessed them, for
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: these poor fools believed that henceforth they should eat their very
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: bread off plates of gold. It was for gold that they had followed Cortes;
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: for gold they had braved the altar of sacrifice and fought in a hundred
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fights, and now, as they thought, they had won it.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: The room of the stone house where they prisoned me had a window secured
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: by bars of wood, and through these bars I could see and hear the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: revellings of the soldiers during the time of my confinement. All day
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: long, when they were not on duty, and most of the night also, they
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: gambled and drank, staking tens of pesos on a single throw, which
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the loser must pay out of his share of the countless treasures of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Aztecs. Little did they care if they won or lost, they were so sure
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of plunder, but played on till drink overpowered them, and they rolled
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: senseless beneath the tables, or till they sprang up and danced wildly
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to and fro, catching at the sunbeams and screaming 'Gold! gold! gold!'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Listening at this window also I gathered some of the tidings of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: camp. I learned that Cortes had come back, bringing Guatemoc and several
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of the princes with him, together with many of the noble Aztec ladies.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Indeed I saw and heard the soldiers gambling for these women when they
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: were weary of their play for money, a description of each of them
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: being written on a piece of paper. One of these ladies answered well to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie, my wife, and she was put up to auction by the brute who won her
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: in the gamble, and sold to a common soldier for a hundred pesos. For
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: these men never doubted but that the women and the gold would be handed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: over to them.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Thus things went for several days, during which I sat and slept in my
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: prison untroubled by any, except the native woman who waited on me and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: brought me food in plenty. During those days I ate as I have never eaten
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: before or since, and I slept much, for my sorrows could not rid my body
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of its appetites and commanding need for food and rest. Indeed I verily
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: believe that at the end of a week, I had increased in weight by a full
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: half; also my weariness was conquered at length, and I was strong again.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: But when I was neither sleeping nor eating I watched at my window,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: hoping, though in vain, to catch some sight of Otomie or of Guatemoc.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: If I might not see my friends, however, at least I saw my foe, for one
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: evening de Garcia came and stared at my prison. He could not see me, but
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I saw him, and the devilish smile that flickered on his face as he went
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: away like a wolf, made me shiver with a presage of woes to come. For ten
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: minutes or more he stood gazing at my window hungrily, as a cat gazes at
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: a caged bird, and I felt that he was waiting for the door to be opened,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and KNEW that it would soon be opened.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: This happened on the eve of the day upon which I was put to torture.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Meanwhile, as time went on, I noticed that a change came over the temper
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of the camp. The soldiers ceased to gamble for untold wealth, they even
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ceased from drinking to excess and from their riotous joy, but took to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: hanging together in knots discussing fiercely I could not learn of what.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: On the day when de Garcia came to look at my prison there was a great
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: gathering in the square opposite my prison, to which I saw Cortes ride
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: up on a white horse and richly dressed. The meeting was too far away for
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: me to overhear what passed, but I noted that several officers addressed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Cortes angrily, and that their speeches were loudly cheered by the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: soldiers. At length the great captain answered them at some length, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: they broke up in silence. Next morning after I had breakfasted, four
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: soldiers came into my prison and ordered me to accompany them.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Whither?' I asked.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'To the captain, traitor,' their leader answered.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'It has come at last,' I thought to myself, but I said only:
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'It is well. Any change from this hole is one for the better.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Certainly,' he replied; 'and it is your last shift.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Then I knew that the man believed that I was going to my death. In five
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: minutes I was standing before Cortes in his private house. At his side
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: was Marina and around him were several of his companions in arms. The
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: great man looked at me for a while, then spoke.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Your name is Wingfield; you are of mixed blood, half English and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: half Spanish. You were cast away in the Tobasco River and taken to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Tenoctitlan. There you were doomed to personate the Aztec god Tezcat,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and were rescued by us when we captured the great teocalli. Subsequently
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: you joined the Aztecs and took part in the attack and slaughter of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: noche triste. You were afterwards the friend and counsellor of Guatemoc,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and assisted him in his defence of Tenoctitlan. Is this true, prisoner?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'It is all true, general,' I answered.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Good. You are now our prisoner, and had you a thousand lives, you have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: forfeited them all because of your treachery to your race and blood.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Into the circumstances that led you to commit this horrible treason I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: cannot enter; the fact remains. You have slain many of the Spaniards
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and their allies; that is, being in a state of treason you have murdered
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: them. Wingfield, your life is forfeit and I condemn you to die by
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: hanging as a traitor and an apostate.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Then there is nothing more to be said,' I answered quietly, though a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: cold fear froze my blood.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'There is something,' answered Cortes. 'Though your crimes have been so
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: many, I am ready to give you your life and freedom upon a condition.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I am ready to do more, to find you a passage to Europe on the first
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: occasion, where you may perchance escape the echoes of your infamy if
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: God is good to you. The condition is this. We have reason to believe
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'No, husband. Two days since I was separated from my sister Tecuichpo
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and the other ladies, but I have been well treated and have seen no
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Spaniard except the soldiers who led me here, telling me that you were
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: sick. Alas! I knew not from what cause,' and again she began to weep.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Still some have seen you and it is reported that you are my wife.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'It is likely enough,' she answered, 'for it was known throughout the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Aztec hosts, and such secrets cannot be kept. But why have they treated
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: you thus? Because you fought against them?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Are we alone?' I asked.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'The guard is without, but there are none else in the chamber.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Then bend down your head and I will tell you,' and I told her all.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: When I had done so she sprang up with flashing eyes and her hand pressed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: upon her breast, and said:
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Oh! if I loved you before, now I love you more if that is possible, who
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: could suffer thus horribly and yet be faithful to the fallen and your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: oath. Blessed be the day when first I looked upon your face, O my
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: husband, most true of men. But they who could do this--what of them?
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Still it is done with and I will nurse you back to health. Surely it is
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: done with, or they had not suffered me to come to you?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Alas! Otomie, I must tell all--it is NOT done with,' and with faltering
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: voice I went on with the tale, yes, and since I must, I told her for
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: what purpose she had been brought here. She listened without a word,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: though her lips turned pale.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Truly,' she said when I had done, 'these Teules far surpass the pabas
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of our people, for if the priests torture and sacrifice, it is to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the gods and not for gold and secret hate. Now, husband, what is your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: counsel? Surely you have some counsel.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I have none that I dare offer, wife,' I groaned.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You are timid as a girl who will not utter the love she burns to tell,'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie answered with a proud and bitter laugh. 'Well, I will speak it
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: for you. It is in your mind that we must die to-night.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'It is,' I said; 'death now, or shame and agony to-morrow and then death
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: at last, that is our choice. Since God will not protect us, we must
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: protect ourselves if we can find the means.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'God! there is no God. At times I have doubted the gods of my people and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: turned to yours; now I renounce and reject Him. If there were a God of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: mercy such as you cling to, could He suffer that such things be? You are
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: my god, husband, to you and for you I pray, and you alone. Let us have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: done now with pleading to those who are not, or who, if they live,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: are deaf to our cries and blind to our misery, and befriend ourselves.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Yonder lies rope, that window has bars, very soon we can be beyond the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: sun and the cruelty of Teules, or sound asleep. But there is time yet;
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: let us talk a while, they will scarcely begin their torments before the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: dawn, and ere dawn we shall be far.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: So we talked as well as my sufferings would allow. We talked of how we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: first had met, of how Otomie had been vowed to me as the wife of Tezcat,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stone of sacrifice, of our true marriage thereafter, of the siege
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of Tenoctitlan and the death of our first-born. Thus we talked till
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: midnight was two hours gone. Then there came a silence.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Husband,' said Otomie at last in a hushed and solemn voice, 'you are
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: worn with suffering, and I am weary. It is time to do that which must
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: be done. Sad is our fate, but at least rest is before us. I thank you,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: husband, for your gentleness, I thank you more for your faithfulness to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: my house and people. Shall I make ready for our last journey?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Make ready!' I answered.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Then she rose and soon was busy with the ropes. At length all was
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: prepared and the moment of death was at hand.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You must aid me, Otomie,' I said; 'I cannot walk by myself.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: She came and lifted me with her strong and tender arms, till I stood
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: upon a stool beneath the window bars. There she placed the rope about my
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: throat, then taking her stand by me she fitted the second rope upon her
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: own. Now we kissed in solemn silence, for there was nothing more to say.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Yet Otomie said something, asking:
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Of whom do you think in this moment, husband? Of me and of my dead
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: child, or of that lady who lives far across the sea? Nay, I will not
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ask. I have been happy in my love, it is enough. Now love and life must
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: end together, and it is well for me, but for you I grieve. Say, shall I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: thrust away the stool?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Yes, Otomie, since there is no hope but death. I cannot break my faith
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with Guatemoc, nor can I live to see you shamed and tortured.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Then kiss me first and for the last time.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stool from beneath us, the door opened and shut, and a veiled woman
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stood before us, bearing a torch in one hand and a bundle in the other.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: She looked, and seeing us and our dreadful purpose, ran to us.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

text: can.'

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stood before Marina.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You are Marina,' she said coldly and proudly, 'and you come to save
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: had my way, I would have none of your salvation, nay, I would rather
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: save myself as I was about to do.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and trembled before Otomie's contempt. They were a strange contrast in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Say, royal lady,' asked Marina in her gentle voice, 'for what cause
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: altar, for this same cause I have striven against the children of my
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

text: again, staring at him wildly--the naked sword in her hand.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: on red hot irons in my dream. Then came a vision of armed men with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)
