text: CHAPTER XXXI
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: OTOMIE PLEADS WITH HER PEOPLE
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: When I awoke it was to find myself in a cave, where the light shone very
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: dimly. Otomie leant over me, and not far away a man was cooking a pot
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: over a fire made of dry aloe leaves.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Where am I and what has happened?' I asked.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You are safe, beloved,' she answered, 'at least for awhile. When you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: have eaten I will tell you more.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: She brought me broth and food and I ate eagerly, and when I was
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: satisfied she spoke.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You remember how the Tlascalan followed us and how--I was rid of him?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I remember, Otomie, though how you found strength to kill him I do not
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: understand.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Love and despair gave it to me, and I pray that I may never have such
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: another need. Do not speak of it, husband, for this is more horrible to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: me than all that has been before. One thing comforts me, however; I did
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: not kill him, the sword twisted in my hand and I believe that he was
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: but stunned. Then we fled a little way, and looking back I saw that two
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: other Tlascalans, companions of the senseless man, were following us
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and him. Presently, they came up to where he lay and stared at him. Then
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: they started on our tracks, running hard, and very soon they must have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: caught us, for now you could scarcely stir, your mind was gone, and I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: had no more strength to carry you. Still we stumbled on till presently,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: when the pursuers were within fifty paces of us, I saw armed men, eight
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of them, rushing at us from the bushes. They were of my own people, the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomies, soldiers that had served under you, who watched the Spanish
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: camp, and seeing a Spaniard alone they came to slay him. They very
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: nearly did so indeed, for at first I was so breathless that I could
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: scarcely speak, but at last in few words I made shift to declare my name
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and rank, and your sad plight. By now the two Tlascalans were upon us,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and I called to the men of the Otomie to protect us, and falling on the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Tlascalans before they knew that enemies were there, they killed one of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: them and took the other prisoner. Then they made a litter, and placing
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: you on it, bore you without rest twenty leagues into the mountains, till
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: they reached this secret hiding place, and here you have lain three days
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and nights. The Teules have searched for you far and wide, but they have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: searched in vain. Only yesterday two of them with ten Tlascalans, passed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: within a hundred paces of this cave and I had much ado to prevent our
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: people from attacking them. Now they are gone whence they came, and I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: think that we are safe for a time. Soon you will be better and we can go
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: hence.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Where can we go to, Otomie? We are birds without a nest.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'We must seek shelter in the City of Pines, or fly across the water;
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: there is no other choice, husband.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'We cannot try the sea, Otomie, for all the ships that come here are
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Spanish, and I do not know how they will greet us in the City of Pines
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: now that our cause is lost, and with it so many thousands of their
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: warriors.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'We must take the risk, husband. There are still true hearts in Anahuac,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: who will stand by us in our sorrow and their own. At the least we have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: escaped from greater dangers. Now let me dress your wounds and rest
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: awhile.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: So for three more days I lay in the cave of the mountains and Otomie
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: tended me, and at the end of that time my state was such that I could
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: travel in a litter, though for some weeks I was unable to set foot to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the ground. On the fourth day we started by night, and I was carried on
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: men's shoulders till at length we passed up the gorge that leads to the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: City of Pines. Here we were stopped by sentries to whom Otomie told our
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: tale, bidding some of them go forward and repeat it to the captains of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the city. We followed the messengers slowly, for my bearers were weary,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and came to the gates of the beautiful town just as the red rays of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: sunset struck upon the snowy pinnacle of Xaca that towers behind it,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: turning her cap of smoke to a sullen red, like that of molten iron.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: The news of our coming had spread about, and here and there knots of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: people were gathered to watch us pass. For the most part they stood
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: silent, but now and again some woman whose husband or son had perished
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: in the siege, would hiss a curse at us.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Alas! how different was our state this day to what it had been when not
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: a year before we entered the City of Pines for the first time. Then we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: were escorted by an army ten thousand strong, then musicians had sung
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: before us and our path was strewn with flowers. And now! Now we came two
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fugitives from the vengeance of the Teules, I borne in a litter by four
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: tired soldiers, while Otomie, the princess of this people, still clad in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: her wanton's robe, at which the women mocked, for she had been able to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: come by no other, tramped at my side, since there were none to carry
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: her, and the inhabitants of the place cursed us as the authors of their
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: woes. Nor did we know if they would stop at words.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: At length we crossed the square beneath the shadow of the teocalli, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: reached the ancient and sculptured palace as the light failed, and the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: smoke on Xaca, the holy hill, began to glow with the fire in its heart.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Here small preparation had been made to receive us, and that night we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: supped by the light of a torch upon tortillas or meal cakes and water,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: like the humblest in the land. Then we crept to our rest, and as I lay
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: awake because of the pain of my hurts, I heard Otomie, who thought that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I slept, break into low sobbing at my side. Her proud spirit was humbled
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: at last, and she, whom I had never known to weep except once, when our
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: firstborn died in the siege, wept bitterly.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Why do you sorrow thus, Otomie?' I asked at length.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I did not know that you were awake, husband,' she sobbed in answer,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'or I would have checked my grief. Husband, I sorrow over all that has
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: befallen us and my people--also, though these are but little things,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: because you are brought low and treated as a man of no estate, and of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the cold comfort that we find here.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'You have cause, wife,' I answered. 'Say, what will these Otomies do
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with us--kill us, or give us up to the Teules?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I do not know; to-morrow we shall learn, but for my part I will not be
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: surrendered living.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Nor I, wife. Death is better than the tender mercies of Cortes and his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: minister, de Garcia. Is there any hope?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Yes, there is hope, beloved. Now the Otomie are cast down and they
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: remember that we led the flower of their land to death. But they are
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: brave and generous at heart, and if I can touch them there, all may yet
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: be well. Weariness, pain and memory make us weak, who should be full of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: courage, having escaped so many ills. Sleep, my husband, and leave me to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: think. All shall yet go well, for even misfortune has an end.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: So I slept, and woke in the morning somewhat refreshed and with a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: happier mind, for who is there that is not bolder when the light shines
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: on him and he is renewed by rest?
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: When I opened my eyes the sun was already high, but Otomie had risen
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with the dawn and she had not been idle during those three hours.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: For one thing she had contrived to obtain food and fresh raiment more
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: befitting to our rank than the rags in which we were clothed. Also she
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: had brought together certain men of condition who were friendly and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: loyal to her in misfortune, and these she sent about the city, letting
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: it be known that she would address the people at mid-day from the steps
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of the palace, for as Otomie knew well, the heartstrings of a crowd are
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: touched more easily than those of cold and ancient counsellors.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Will they come to listen?' I asked.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Have no fear,' she answered. 'The desire to look upon us who have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: survived the siege, and to know the truth of what has happened, will
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: bring them. Moreover, some will be there seeking vengeance on us.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie was right, for as the morning drew on towards mid-day, I saw the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: dwellers in the City of Pines gathering in thousands, till the space
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: between the steps of the palace and the face of the pyramid was black
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with them. Now Otomie combed her curling hair and placed flowers in it,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and set a gleaming feather cloak about her shoulders, so that it hung
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: down over her white robes, and on her breast that splendid necklace of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: emeralds which Guatemoc had given to me in the treasure chamber, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: which she had preserved safely through all our evil fortune, and a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: golden girdle about her waist. In her hand also she took a little
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: sceptre of ebony tipped with gold, that was in the palace, with other
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ornaments and emblems of rank, and thus attired, though she was worn
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with travel and suffering, and grief had dimmed her beauty for a while,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: she seemed the queenliest woman that my eyes have seen. Next she caused
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: me to be laid upon my rude litter, and when the hour of noon was come,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: she commanded those soldiers who had borne me across the mountains to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: carry me by her side. Thus we issued from the wide doorway of the palace
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and took our stand upon the platform at the head of the steps. As we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: came a great cry rose from the thousands of the people, a fierce cry
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: like that of wild beasts howling for their prey. Higher and higher it
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: rose, a sound to strike terror into the bravest heart, and by degrees I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: caught its purport.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Kill them!' said the cry. 'Give the liars to the Teules.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

text: ebony sceptre she stood silent, the sunlight beating on her lovely face
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and form. But the multitude screamed a thousand taunts and threats at
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: us, and still the tumult grew. Once they rushed towards her as though
title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

text: from a rock, and once a spear was thrown that passed between her neck

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and shoulder.

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: at hand, and having no wish to share it, set my litter down upon the
title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: before them stately and scornful, a very queen among women, and little
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: by little the majesty of her presence and the greatness of her courage
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: hushed them to silence. When there was quiet at length, she spoke in a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: clear voice that carried far.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Am I among my own people of the Otomie?' she asked bitterly, 'or have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: put another heart into us. You are right; it is better to die free than
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to live as slaves.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'See, my husband,' said Otomie, 'I was not mistaken when I told you that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: my people were loyal and true. But now we must make ready for war, for
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: they have gone too far to turn back, and when this tidings comes to the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ears of Malinche he will be like a puma robbed of her young. Now, let us
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: rest, I am very weary.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Otomie,' I answered, 'there has lived no greater woman than you upon
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: this earth.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I cannot tell, husband,' she said, smiling; 'if I have won your praise
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and safety, it is enough for me.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: CHAPTER XXXII
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: THE END OF GUATEMOC
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Now for a while we dwelt in quiet at the City of Pines, and by slow
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: degrees and with much suffering I recovered from the wounds that the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: cruel hand of de Garcia had inflicted upon me. But we knew that this
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: peace could not last, and the people of the Otomie knew it also, for had
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: they not scourged the envoys of Malinche out of the gates of their city?
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Many of them were now sorry that this had been done, but it was done,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and they must reap as they had sown.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: So they made ready for war, and Otomie was the president of their
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: councils, in which I shared. At length came news that a force of fifty
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Spaniards with five thousand Tlascalan allies were advancing on the city
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to destroy us. Then I took command of the tribesmen of the Otomie--there
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: were ten thousand or more of them, all well-armed after their own
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fashion--and advanced out of the city till I was two-thirds of the way
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: down the gorge which leads to it. But I did not bring all my army down
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: this gorge, since there was no room for them to fight there, and I had
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: another plan. I sent some seven thousand men round the mountains, of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: which the secret paths were well known to them, bidding them climb to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the crest of the precipices that bordered either side of the gorge,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and there, at certain places where the cliff is sheer and more than one
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: thousand feet in height, to make a great provision of stones.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: The rest of my army, excepting five hundred whom I kept with me, I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: armed with bows and throwing spears, and stationed them in ambush in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: convenient places where the sides of the cliff were broken, and in such
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fashion that rocks from above could not be rolled on them. Then I sent
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: trusty men as spies to warn me of the approach of the Spaniards, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: others whose mission it was to offer themselves to them as guides.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Now I thought my plan good, and everything looked well, and yet it
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: missed failure but by a very little. For Maxtla, our enemy and the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: friend of the Spaniards, was in my camp--indeed, I had brought him with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: me that I might watch him--and he had not been idle.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: For when the Spaniards were half a day's march from the mouth of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: defile, one of those men whom I had told off to watch their advance,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: came to me and made it known that Maxtla had bribed him to go to the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: leader of the Spaniards and disclose to him the plan of the ambuscade.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: This man had taken the bribe and started on his errand of treachery,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: but his heart failed him and, returning, he told me all. Then I caused
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Maxtla to be seized, and before nightfall he had paid the price of his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: wickedness.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: On the morning after his death the Spanish array entered the pass.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Half-way down it I met them with my five hundred men and engaged them,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: but suffered them to drive us back with some loss. As they followed they
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: grew bolder and we fled faster, till at length we flew down the defile
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: followed by the Spanish horse. Now, some three furlongs from its mouth
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that leads to the City of Pines, this pass turns and narrows, and here
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the cliffs are so sheer and high that a twilight reigns at the foot of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: them.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Down the narrow way we ran in seeming rout, and after us came the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Spaniards shouting on their saints and flushed with victory. But
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: scarcely had we turned the corner when they sang another song, for those
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: who were watching a thousand feet above us gave the signal, and down
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: from on high came a rain of stones and boulders that darkened the air
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and crashed among them, crushing many of them. On they struggled, seeing
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: a wider way in front where the cliffs sloped, and perhaps half of them
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: won through. But here the archers were waiting, and now, in the place of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: stones, arrows were hailed upon them, till at length, utterly bewildered
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and unable to strike a blow in their own defence, they turned to fly
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: towards the open country. This finished the fight, for now we assailed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: their flank, and once more the rocks thundered on them from above, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the end of it was that those who remained of the Spaniards and their
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Indian allies were driven in utter rout back to the plain beyond the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Pass of Pines.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: After this battle the Spaniards troubled us no more for many years
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: except by threats, and my name grew great among the people of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: One Spaniard I rescued from death and afterwards I gave him his liberty.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: From him I inquired of the doings of de Garcia or Sarceda, and learned
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that he was still in the service of Cortes, but that Marina had been
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: true to her word, and had brought disgrace upon him because he had
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: threatened to put Otomie to the torture. Moreover Cortes was angry with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: him because of our escape, the burden of which Marina had laid upon his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: shoulders, hinting that he had taken a bribe to suffer us to pass the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: gate.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Of the fourteen years of my life which followed the defeat of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Spaniards I can speak briefly, for compared to the time that had gone
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: before they were years of quiet. In them children were born to me and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie, three sons, and these children were my great joy, for I loved
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: them dearly and they loved me. Indeed, except for the strain of their
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: mother's blood, they were English boys and not Indian, for I christened
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: them all, and taught them our English tongue and faith, and their mien
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and eyes were more English than Indian, though their skins were dark.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: But I had no luck with these dear children of mine, any more than I have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: had with that which Lily bore me. Two of them died--one from a fever
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that all my skill would not avail to cure, and another by a fall from a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: lofty cedar tree, which he climbed searching for a kite's nest. Thus
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of the three of them--since I do not speak now of that infant, my
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: firstborn, who perished in the siege--there remained to me only the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: eldest and best beloved of whom I must tell hereafter.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: For the rest, jointly with Otomie I was named cacique of the City
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of Pines at a great council that was held after I had destroyed the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Spaniards and their allies, and as such we had wide though not absolute
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: power. By the exercise of this power, in the end I succeeded in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: abolishing the horrible rites of human sacrifice, though, because of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: this, a large number of the outlying tribes fell away from our rule, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the enmity of the priests was excited against me. The last sacrifice,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: except one only, the most terrible of them all, of which I will tell
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: afterwards, that was ever celebrated on the teocalli in front of the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: palace, took place after the defeat of the Spaniards in the pass.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: When I had dwelt three years in the City of Pines and two sons had
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: been born to me there, secret messengers arrived that were sent by
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the friends of Guatemoc, who had survived the torture and was still a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: prisoner in the hands of Cortes. From these messengers we learned that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Cortes was about to start upon an expedition to the Gulf of Honduras,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: across the country that is now known as Yucatan, taking Guatemoc and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: other Aztec nobles with him for he feared to leave them behind. We heard
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: also that there was much murmuring among the conquered tribes of Anahuac
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: because of the cruelties and extortions of the Spaniards, and many
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: thought that the hour had come when a rising against them might be
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: carried to a successful issue.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: This was the prayer of those who sent the envoys, that I should raise a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: force of Otomies and travel with it across the country to Yucatan, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: there with others who would be gathered, wait a favourable opportunity
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to throw myself upon the Spaniards when they were entangled in the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: forests and swamps, putting them to the sword and releasing Guatemoc.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Such was the first purpose of the plot, though it had many others of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: which it is useless to speak, seeing that they came to nothing.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: When the message had been delivered I shook my head sadly, for I could
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: see no hope in such a scheme, but the chief of the messengers rose and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: led me aside, saying that he had a word for my ear.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Guatemoc sends these words,' he said; 'I hear that you, my brother, are
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: free and safe with my cousin Otomie in the mountains of the Otomie. I,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: alas! linger in the prisons of the Teules like a crippled eagle in a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: cage. My brother, if it is in your power to help me, do so I conjure
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: you by the memory of our ancient friendship, and of all that we have
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: suffered together. Then a time may still come when I shall rule again in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Anahuac, and you shall sit at my side.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I heard and my heart was stirred, for then, as to this hour, I loved
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Guatemoc as a brother.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Go back,' I said, 'and find means to tell Guatemoc that if I can save
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: him I will, though I have small hopes that way. Still, let him look for
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: me in the forests of Yucatan.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Now when Otomie heard of this promise of mine she was vexed, for she
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: said that it was foolish and would only end in my losing my life. Still,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: having given it she held with me that it must be carried out, and the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: end of it was that I raised five hundred men, and with them set out upon
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: my long and toilsome march, which I timed so as to meet Cortes in the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: passes of Yucatan. At the last moment Otomie wished to accompany me, but
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I forbade it, pointing out that she could leave neither her children nor
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: her people, and we parted with bitter grief for the first time.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Of all the hardships that I underwent I will not write. For two and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: a half months we struggled on across mountains and rivers and through
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: swamps and forests, till at last we reached a mighty deserted city,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that is called Palenque by the Indians of those parts, which has been
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: uninhabited for many generations. This city is the most marvellous place
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that I have seen in all my travels, though much of it is hidden in
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: bush, for wherever the traveller wanders there he finds vast palaces of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: marble, carven within and without, and sculptured teocallis and the huge
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: images of grinning gods. Often have I wondered what nation was strong
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: enough to build such a capital, and who were the kings that dwelt in it.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: But these are secrets belonging to the past, and they cannot be answered
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: till some learned man has found the key to the stone symbols and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: writings with which the walls of the buildings are covered over.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: In this city I hid with my men, though it was no easy task to persuade
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: them to take up their habitation among so many ghosts of the departed,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: not to speak of the noisome fevers and the wild beasts and snakes that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: haunted it, for I had information that the Spaniards would pass through
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the swamp that lies between the ruins and the river, and there I hoped
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to ambush them. But on the eighth day of my hiding I learned from spies
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that Cortes had crossed the great river higher up, and was cutting his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: way through the forest, for of swamps he had passed more than enough. So
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I hurried also to the river intending to cross it. But all that day and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: all that night it rained as it can rain nowhere else in the world that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I have seen, till at last we waded on our road knee deep in water, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: when we came to the ford of the river it was to find a wide roaring

text: CHAPTER XXXIII
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ISABELLA DE SIGUENZA IS AVENGED
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: For many years after the death of Guatemoc I lived with Otomie at peace
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: in the City of Pines. Our country was poor and rugged, and though we
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: defied the Spaniards and paid them no tribute, now that Cortes had gone
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: back to Spain, they had no heart to attempt our conquest. Save some few
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: And now it may be asked was I happy in those years? I had much to make
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: rough-looking, thick-set man well on in years, with bright eyes and an
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ugly honest face, like the face of a peasant who has toiled a lifetime
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: in all weathers, only the fields that Diaz tilled were fields of war,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and his harvest had been the lives of men. Just then he was joking with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: some common soldiers in a strain scarcely suited to nice ears, but so
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: soon as he saw us he ceased and came forward. I saluted him after the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Indian fashion by touching the earth with my hand, for what was I but an
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Indian captive?
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Your sword,' he said briefly, as he scanned me with his quick eyes.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I unbuckled it from my side and handed it to him, saying in Spanish:
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Take it, Captain, for you have conquered, also it does but come back
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to its owner.' For this was the same sword that I had captured from one
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Bernal Diaz in the fray of the noche triste.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: He looked at it, then swore a great oath and said:
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I thought that it could be no other man. And so we meet again thus
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: after so many years. Well, you gave me my life once, and I am glad that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I have lived to pay the debt. Had I not been sure that it was you, you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: had not won such easy terms, friend. How are you named? Nay, I know what
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the Indians call you.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I am named Wingfield.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Friend Wingfield then. For I tell you that I would have sat beneath
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: yonder devil's house,' and he nodded towards the teocalli, 'till you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: starved upon its top. Nay, friend Wingfield, take back the sword. I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: suited myself with another many years ago, and you have used this one
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: gallantly; never have I seen Indians make a better fight. And so that is
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Otomie, Montezuma's daughter and your wife, still handsome and royal,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I see. Lord! Lord! it is many years ago, and yet it seems but yesterday
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that I saw her father die, a Christian-hearted man, though no Christian,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and one whom we dealt ill with. May God forgive us all! Well, Madam,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: none can say that YOU have a Christian heart. If a certain tale that I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: have heard of what passed yonder, some three nights since, is true. But
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: we will speak no more of it, for the savage blood will show, and you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: are pardoned for your husband's sake who saved my comrades from the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: sacrifice.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: To all this Otomie listened, standing still like a statue, but she never
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: answered a word. Indeed she had spoken very rarely since that dreadful
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: night of her unspeakable shame.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'And now, friend Wingfield,' went on the Captain Diaz, 'what is your
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: purpose? You are free to go where you will, whither then will you go?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I do not know,' I answered. 'Years ago, when the Aztec emperor gave me
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: my life and this princess my wife in marriage, I swore to be faithful
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to him and his cause, and to fight for them till Popo ceased to vomit
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: smoke, till there was no king in Tenoctitlan, and the people of Anahuac
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: were no more a people.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Then you are quit of your oath, friend, for all these things have come
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: about, and there has been no smoke on Popo for these two years. Now, if
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: you will be advised by me, you will turn Christian again and enter
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the service of Spain. But come, let us to supper, we can talk of these
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: matters afterwards.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: So we sat down to eat by the light of torches in the banqueting hall
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: with Bernal Diaz and some other of the Spaniards. Otomie would have left
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: us, and though the captain bade her stay she ate nothing, and presently
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: slipped away from the chamber.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: CHAPTER XXXVII
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: VENGEANCE
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: During that meal Bernal Diaz spoke of our first meeting on the causeway,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: and of how I had gone near to killing him in error, thinking that he was
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Sarceda, and then he asked me what was my quarrel with Sarceda.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: In as few words as possible I told him the story of my life, of all the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: evil that de Garcia or Sarceda had worked upon me and mine, and of how
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: it was through him that I was in this land that day. He listened amazed.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Holy Mother!' he said at length, 'I always knew him for a villain, but
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: that, if you do not lie, friend Wingfield, he could be such a man as
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: this, I did not know. Now by my word, had I heard this tale an hour
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ago, Sarceda should not have left this camp till he had answered it or
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: cleared himself by combat with you. But I fear it is too late; he was to
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: leave for Mexico at the rising of the moon, to stir up mischief against
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: me because I granted you terms--not that I fear him there, where his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: repute is small.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I do not lie indeed,' I answered. 'Much of this tale I can prove if
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: need be, and I tell you that I would give half the life that is left
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to me to stand face to face in open fight with him again. Ever he has
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: escaped me, and the score between us is long.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Now as I spoke thus it seemed to me that a cold and dreadful air played
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: upon my hands and brow and a warning sense of present evil crept into my
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: soul, overcoming me so that I could not stir or speak for a while.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Let us go and see if he has gone,' said Diaz presently, and summoning
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: a guard, he was about to leave the chamber. It was at this moment that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I chanced to look up and see a woman standing in the doorway. Her hand
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: rested on the doorpost; her head, from which the long hair streamed, was
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: thrown back, and on her face was a look of such anguish that at first,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: so much was she changed, I did not know her for Otomie. When I knew her,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I knew all; one thing only could conjure up the terror and agony that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: shone in her deep eyes.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'What has chanced to our son?' I asked.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'DEAD, DEAD!' she answered in a whisper that seemed to pierce my marrow.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I said nothing, for my heart told me what had happened, but Diaz asked,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Dead--why, what has killed him?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'De Garcia! I saw him go,' replied Otomie; then she tossed her arms
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: high, and without another sound fell backwards to the earth.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: In that moment I think that my heart broke--at least I know that nothing
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: has had the power to move me greatly since, though this memory moves me
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: day by day and hour by hour, till I die and go to seek my son.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Say, Bernal Diaz,' I cried, with a hoarse laugh, 'did I lie to you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: concerning this comrade of yours?'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Then, springing over Otomie's body I left the chamber, followed by
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Bernal Diaz and the others.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Without the door I turned to the left towards the camp. I had not gone
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: a hundred paces when, in the moonlight, I saw a small troop of horsemen
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: riding towards us. It was de Garcia and his servants, and they headed
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: towards the mountain pass on their road to Mexico. I was not too late.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Halt!' cried Bernal Diaz.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'Who commands me to halt?' said the voice of de Garcia.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'I, your captain,' roared Diaz. 'Halt, you devil, you murderer, or you
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: shall be cut down.'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I saw him start and turn pale.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: 'These are strange manners, senor,' he said. 'Of your grace I ask--'
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: At this moment de Garcia caught sight of me for the first time, for I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: had broken from the hold of Diaz who clutched my arm, and was moving
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: towards him. I said nothing, but there was something in my face which
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: told him that I knew all, and warned him of his doom. He looked past me,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: but the narrow road was blocked with men. I drew near, but he did
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: not wait for me. Once he put his hand on the hilt of the sword, then
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: suddenly he wheeled his horse round and fled down the street of Xaca.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: De Garcia fled, and I followed after him, running fast and low like a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: hound. At first he gained on me, but soon the road grew rough, and he
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: could not gallop over it. We were clear of the town now, or rather of
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: its ruins, and travelling along a little path which the Indians used
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to bring down snow from Xaca in the hot weather. Perhaps there are some
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: five miles of this path before the snow line is reached, beyond which no
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Indian dared to set his foot, for the ground above was holy. Along this
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: path he went, and I was content to see it, for I knew well that the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: traveller cannot leave it, since on either side lie water-courses and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: cliffs. Mile after mile de Garcia followed it, looking now to the left,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: now to the right, and now ahead at the great dome of snow crowned with
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fire that towered above him. But he never looked behind him; he knew
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: what was there--death in the shape of a man!
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: I came on doggedly, saving my strength. I was sure that I must catch him
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: at last, it did not matter when.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: At length he reached the snow-line where the path ended, and for the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: first time he looked back. There I was some two hundred paces behind
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: him. I, his death, was behind him, and in front of him shone the snow.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: For a moment he hesitated, and I heard the heavy breathing of his horse
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: in the great stillness. Then he turned and faced the slope, driving his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: spurs into the brute's sides. The snow was hard, for here the frost bit
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: sharply, and for a while, though it was so steep, the horse travelled
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: over it better than he had done along the pathway. Now, as before, there
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: was only one road that he could take, for we passed up the crest of a
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: ridge, a pleat as it were in the garment of the mountain, and on either
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: side were steeps of snow on which neither horse nor man might keep his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: footing. For two hours or more we followed that ridge, and as we went
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: through the silence of the haunted volcan, and the loneliness of its
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: eternal snows, it seemed to me that my spirit entered into the spirit
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: of my quarry, and that with its eyes I saw all that was passing in his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: heart. To a man so wronged the dream was pleasant even if it were not
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: true, for I read there such agony, such black despair, such haunting
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: memories, such terror of advancing death and of what lay beyond it, that
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: no revenge of man's could surpass their torment. And it was true--I
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: knew that it was true; he suffered all this and more, for if he had no
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: conscience, at least he had fear and imagination to quicken and multiply
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: the fear.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: Now the snow grew steeper, and the horse was almost spent, for he could
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: scarcely breathe at so great a height. In vain did de Garcia drive his
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: spurs into its sides, the gallant beast could do no more. Suddenly it
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fell down. Surely, I thought, he will await me now. But even I had not
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fathomed the depth of his terrors, for de Garcia disengaged himself
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: from the fallen horse, looked towards me, then fled forward on his feet,
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: casting away his armour as he went that he might travel more lightly.
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: fires, or perhaps by that of the sun in hot seasons, I know not, and
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: to needle of rough ice, that stand upon the smooth surface like the
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

text: him, and, strange to say, he obeyed me without question, forgetting

text: your gods and I seek my own, though I think that I love yours and hate
title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider)

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter

title: Montezuma's Daughter
